misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing mental model (arrays indexed from 1 to N)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays in Java are indexed starting at 1 (so the first element is at index 1 and the last is at index N).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indexes are 0 through n-1. Using 1..n tries to access y[n] (past the end) and also skips y[0]. This causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime and also shifts the reported ‘index’ compared with the problem’s expected indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) and/or incorrect index reported even if it didn’t crash.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Confusion between 'position in loop' and 'valid array index'
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the loop counter i directly represents a valid position to store/read in the array, as long as i goes up to n.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: A loop counter is just an integer; it only becomes a valid array index if it stays within the array’s bounds (0..n-1). The student’s loop condition i<=n makes i take the value n, which is never a valid index for an array of length n.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception when i becomes n; also the search ignores the element at index 0.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Off-by-one interpretation of “first occurrence” output index
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the index they should print is the same numbering humans often use when counting items (1st, 2nd, 3rd…), rather than Java’s array indexing.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The problem asks for the array index (and the sample uses 0-based indexing: in [10,20,30,20,50], 20 first appears at index 1). If the student counts starting at 1, they would report 2 for that sample. Their code structure (starting i at 1 and printing r directly) matches that 1-based counting model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (index off by one) even in cases where bounds errors are avoided.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays in Java are indexed starting at 1, similar to mathematical notation or everyday counting (1st element, 2nd element, etc.), and that when reading N elements, the loop should iterate from i=1 to i=n and store values at positions y[1] through y[n].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed. Valid indices for an array of size n are 0 through n-1. When the student's code uses y[i] with i starting at 1, it writes to indices 1 through n, leaving index 0 uninitialized and attempting to access y[n], which is out of bounds. This causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when the loop tries to access y[n], which exceeds the valid range [0, n-1]

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index Return vs Element Position Mismatch
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when an element is found at loop iteration i (using 1-based counting in their loop), returning i directly gives the correct index to report to the user.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Because the student's loop uses 1-based indexing but Java arrays are 0-indexed, the loop variable i does not correspond to the actual array index where elements are stored. When an element is found and the student stores r=i, this stores the loop iteration number (1, 2, 3...) rather than the actual 0-based array index (0, 1, 2...). Even if the array access didn't crash, the reported index would be off by one.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Incorrect output: if the target is found, the reported index will be 1 greater than the actual 0-based index (or the program crashes before reaching this point due to ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the memory slots in an array are numbered starting from 1 up to the size of the array (N), rather than starting from 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array indices are zero-based, meaning the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index N-1. Using a loop that goes from 1 to N causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because index N is not a valid position in an array of size N.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays in Java are indexed starting at 1, so the first element goes into y[1] and the last element goes into y[n]. They also believe looping from 1 to n (inclusive) will safely visit every element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0 through n-1. Index n is always out of bounds. A loop that goes i=1; i<=n; i++ will both skip y[0] and attempt to access y[n], which causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) while reading elements and/or while searching; also logically misses the first element at index 0.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Confusion about what index to report vs. human counting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the index they should print is the same as the loop counter they’re using (starting at 1), matching how humans count positions (1st, 2nd, 3rd). So they treat the 'index' as 'position number' rather than Java’s array index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Programming problems that ask for an 'index' in Java typically mean the array index (0-based). If you store/search using 1-based positions, the reported result will be off by one compared to Java indexing (and compared to typical expected outputs).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (off-by-one) if the program didn’t already crash; e.g., would report 2 instead of 1 for the sample if it were adjusted not to crash, and would never be able to report index 0 correctly.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1 (like mathematical sequences or arrays in languages such as MATLAB or Fortran). They think looping from i=1 to i=n (inclusive) correctly iterates through all elements of an array of size n.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap:
In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array of size n has valid indices from 0 to n-1. The student's loops attempt to access indices 1 through n, which means:
1. Index 0 is never populated (remains default value 0)
2. Index n is out of bounds—Java will throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
This is a critical difference from mathematical notation or some other programming languages.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when the loop counter reaches n and attempts to access y[n], which does not exist in an array of size n.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array elements are accessed starting with index 1 for the first element and ending with index N for the last element in an array of size N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed, meaning the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index N-1. Starting the loop at 1 skips the first element, and using i <= n as a condition causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because index N is invalid.
